a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 864"
shows  "n = (card {f :: (string \<Rightarrow> string). 
  (\<forall>x. x \<in> {'Anna', 'Betty'} \<longrightarrow> f x \<noteq> 'Goldfish') \<and>
  (\<forall>x. x \<in> {'Charlie', 'Danny'} \<longrightarrow> f x \<in> {'Siamese', 'Persian', 'Calico', 'Minx'}) \<and>
  (\<forall>x. x \<in> {'Child1', 'Child2', 'Child3'} \<longrightarrow> f x \<in> {'Siamese', 'Persian', 'Calico', 'Minx', 'Poodle', 'Golden Retriever', 'Goldfish'}) \<and>
  inj_on f {'Anna', 'Betty', 'Charlie', 'Danny', 'Child1', 'Child2', 'Child3'}})"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 864"
shows  "n = (card {f :: (string \<Rightarrow> string). 
  (\<forall>x. x \<in> {'Anna', 'Betty'} \<longrightarrow> f x \<noteq> 'Goldfish') \<and>
  (\<forall>x. x \<in> {'Charlie', 'Danny'} \<longrightarrow> f x \<in> {'Siamese', 'Persian', 'Calico', 'Minx'}) \<and>
  (\<forall>x. x \<in> {'Child1', 'Child2', 'Child3'} \<longrightarrow> f x \<in> {'Siamese', 'Persian', 'Calico', 'Minx', 'Poodle', 'Golden Retriever', 'Goldfish'}) \<and>
  inj_on f {'Anna', 'Betty', 'Charlie', 'Danny', 'Child1', 'Child2', 'Child3'}})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a group of 7 people, there are 2 mothers, 2 fathers, and 3 children. Each person has a different pet. The mothers do not have a goldfish as a pet. The fathers can have a Siamese cat, a Persian cat, a Calico cat, or a Minx cat. The children can have a Siamese cat, a Persian cat, a Calico cat, a Minx cat, a Poodle, a Golden Retriever, or a Goldfish. How many different combinations of pets can this group have? The final answer is 864.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Siamese Persian Calico Minx Poodle Golden_Retriever Goldfish :: 'a
and Anna Betty Charlie Danny :: 'a => nat
assumes h0 : "distinct [Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, Golden_Retriever, Goldfish]"
and h1 : "Anna \<noteq> Goldfish \<and> Betty \<noteq> Goldfish"
and h2 : "Charlie = Siamese \<or> Charlie = Persian \<or> Charlie = Calico \<or> Charlie = Minx"
and h3 : "Danny = Siamese \<or> Danny = Persian \<or> Danny = Calico \<or> Danny = Minx"
shows  "card {f. bij f \<and> f Anna \<noteq> Goldfish \<and> f Betty \<noteq> Goldfish \<and> (f Charlie = Siamese \<or> f Charlie = Persian \<or> f Charlie = Calico \<or> f Charlie = Minx) \<and> (f Danny = Siamese \<or> f Danny = Persian \<or> f Danny = Calico \<or> f Danny = Minx)} = 864"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes Siamese Persian Calico Minx Poodle Golden_Retriever Goldfish :: 'a
and Anna Betty Charlie Danny :: 'a => nat
assumes h0 : "distinct [Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, Golden_Retriever, Goldfish]"
and h1 : "Anna \<noteq> Goldfish \<and> Betty \<noteq> Goldfish"
and h2 : "Charlie = Siamese \<or> Charlie = Persian \<or> Charlie = Calico \<or> Charlie = Minx"
and h3 : "Danny = Siamese \<or> Danny = Persian \<or> Danny = Calico \<or> Danny = Minx"
shows  "card {f. bij f \<and> f Anna \<noteq> Goldfish \<and> f Betty \<noteq> Goldfish \<and> (f Charlie = Siamese \<or> f Charlie = Persian \<or> f Charlie = Calico \<or> f Charlie = Minx) \<and> (f Danny = Siamese \<or> f Danny = Persian \<or> f Danny = Calico \<or> f Danny = Minx)} = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 4 people (Anna, Betty, Charlie, and Danny) and 7 pets (Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, Golden Retriever, and Goldfish). The pets are all distinct. Anna and Betty cannot own a Goldfish. Charlie and Danny must own a Siamese, Persian, Calico, or Minx. How many ways can these pets be assigned to the owners with the given constraints? The final answer is 864.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cats dogs goldfish :: nat
assumes h0 : "cats = 4"
and h1 : "dogs = 2"
and h2 : "goldfish = 1"
and h3 : "Anna_and_Betty_refuse_goldfish"
and h4 : "Charlie_and_Danny_insist_on_cats"
and h5 : "Eva_Frank_George_will_take_anything"
shows  "number_of_ways_to_give_pets = 864"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes cats dogs goldfish :: nat
assumes h0 : "cats = 4"
and h1 : "dogs = 2"
and h2 : "goldfish = 1"
and h3 : "Anna_and_Betty_refuse_goldfish"
and h4 : "Charlie_and_Danny_insist_on_cats"
and h5 : "Eva_Frank_George_will_take_anything"
shows  "number_of_ways_to_give_pets = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 4 cats, 2 dogs, and 1 goldfish available to give as pets. Anna and Betty refuse to take a goldfish, Charlie and Danny insist on having cats, and Eva, Frank, and George will accept any of the pets. How many ways are there to distribute the pets among these 7 people? The final answer is 864.

a_3.formal problem:
datatype Pet = Siamese | Persian | Calico | Minx | Poodle | GoldenRetriever | Goldfish
datatype Child = Anna | Betty | Charlie | Danny | Child1 | Child2 | Child3

fun allowed_pet :: "Child \<Rightarrow> Pet set" where
"allowed_pet Anna = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever}" |
"allowed_pet Betty = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever}" |
"allowed_pet Charlie = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx}" |
"allowed_pet Danny = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx}" |
"allowed_pet Child1 = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}" |
"allowed_pet Child2 = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}" |
"allowed_pet Child3 = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}"

theorem
fixes f :: "Child \<Rightarrow> Pet"
assumes h0 : "bij_betw f {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, Child3} {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. f c \<in> allowed_pet c"
shows  "card {f . f \<in> extensional {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, Child3} \<and> bij_betw f {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, Child3} {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish} \<and> (\<forall> c. f c \<in> allowed_pet c)} = 864"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

datatype Pet = Siamese | Persian | Calico | Minx | Poodle | GoldenRetriever | Goldfish
datatype Child = Anna | Betty | Charlie | Danny | Child1 | Child2 | Child3

fun allowed_pet :: "Child \<Rightarrow> Pet set" where
"allowed_pet Anna = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever}" |
"allowed_pet Betty = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever}" |
"allowed_pet Charlie = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx}" |
"allowed_pet Danny = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx}" |
"allowed_pet Child1 = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}" |
"allowed_pet Child2 = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}" |
"allowed_pet Child3 = {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}"

theorem
fixes f :: "Child \<Rightarrow> Pet"
assumes h0 : "bij_betw f {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, Child3} {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish}"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. f c \<in> allowed_pet c"
shows  "card {f . f \<in> extensional {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, Child3} \<and> bij_betw f {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, Child3} {Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, GoldenRetriever, Goldfish} \<and> (\<forall> c. f c \<in> allowed_pet c)} = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
There are 7 children: Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, Child1, Child2, and Child3. Each child is allowed to have one of the following pets: Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, Golden Retriever, and Goldfish. The allowed pets for each child are as follows:

- Anna and Betty can have a Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, or Golden Retriever.
- Charlie and Danny can have a Siamese, Persian, Calico, or Minx.
- Child1, Child2, and Child3 can have any of the 7 pets.

Each child must have one pet, and each pet can only belong to one child. How many different ways can the pets be assigned to the children, given the constraints on the allowed pets for each child? The final answer is 864.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cats dogs goldfish total_animals children :: nat
and Anna Betty Charlie Danny :: nat
assumes h0 : "cats = 4"
and h1 : "dogs = 2"
and h2 : "goldfish = 1"
and h3 : "total_animals = cats + dogs + goldfish"
and h4 : "children = 7"
and h5 : "Anna \<noteq> goldfish"
and h6 : "Betty \<noteq> goldfish"
and h7 : "Charlie \<in> {1..cats}"
and h8 : "Danny \<in> {1..cats}"
and h9 : "children - {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny} \<subseteq> {1..total_animals}"
shows  "\<exists>n. n = 864"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes cats dogs goldfish total_animals children :: nat
and Anna Betty Charlie Danny :: nat
assumes h0 : "cats = 4"
and h1 : "dogs = 2"
and h2 : "goldfish = 1"
and h3 : "total_animals = cats + dogs + goldfish"
and h4 : "children = 7"
and h5 : "Anna \<noteq> goldfish"
and h6 : "Betty \<noteq> goldfish"
and h7 : "Charlie \<in> {1..cats}"
and h8 : "Danny \<in> {1..cats}"
and h9 : "children - {Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny} \<subseteq> {1..total_animals}"
shows  "\<exists>n. n = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
In a room, there are 4 cats, 2 dogs, and 1 goldfish. There are also 7 children named Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, and 3 others. Each child has a unique number assigned to them. The following conditions must be met:

1. Anna's number is not the same as the number of goldfish.
2. Betty's number is not the same as the number of goldfish.
3. Charlie's number is between 1 and the number of cats, inclusive.
4. Danny's number is between 1 and the number of cats, inclusive.
5. The numbers assigned to the remaining 3 children are within the range of the total number of animals.

Find a value for n that satisfies the conditions. The final answer is 864.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes animals :: nat and cats dogs goldfish :: nat
and anna betty charlie danny :: nat
and other_children :: nat
assumes h0 : "animals = 7"
and h1 : "cats = 4"
and h2 : "dogs = 2"
and h3 : "goldfish = 1"
and h4 : "anna + betty = 2"
and h5 : "charlie + danny = 2"
and h6 : "other_children = 3"
shows  "NumberOfWays = 864"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes animals :: nat and cats dogs goldfish :: nat
and anna betty charlie danny :: nat
and other_children :: nat
assumes h0 : "animals = 7"
and h1 : "cats = 4"
and h2 : "dogs = 2"
and h3 : "goldfish = 1"
and h4 : "anna + betty = 2"
and h5 : "charlie + danny = 2"
and h6 : "other_children = 3"
shows  "NumberOfWays = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 7 animals in total: 4 cats, 2 dogs, and 1 goldfish. Anna and Betty are responsible for taking care of 2 of the animals, Charlie and Danny are responsible for taking care of another 2, and 3 other children are responsible for the remaining animals. Find the number of ways the animals can be assigned to the children. The final answer is 864.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pets :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "pets 1 = 4"
and h1 : "pets 2 = 2"
and h2 : "pets 3 = 1"
and h3 : "pets 4 = 0"
and h4 : "pets 5 = 0"
and h5 : "pets 6 = 0"
and h6 : "pets 7 = 0"
and h7 : "pets (Suc n) = 0"
and h8 : "Anna \<noteq> pets 3"
and h9 : "Betty \<noteq> pets 3"
and h10 : "Charlie = pets 1"
and h11 : "Danny = pets 1"
shows  "count_ways pets = 864"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes pets :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "pets 1 = 4"
and h1 : "pets 2 = 2"
and h2 : "pets 3 = 1"
and h3 : "pets 4 = 0"
and h4 : "pets 5 = 0"
and h5 : "pets 6 = 0"
and h6 : "pets 7 = 0"
and h7 : "pets (Suc n) = 0"
and h8 : "Anna \<noteq> pets 3"
and h9 : "Betty \<noteq> pets 3"
and h10 : "Charlie = pets 1"
and h11 : "Danny = pets 1"
shows  "count_ways pets = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
In a neighborhood, there are 7 houses. The number of pets in each house is as follows:

1. House 1 has 4 pets
2. House 2 has 2 pets
3. House 3 has 1 pet
4. House 4 has 0 pets
5. House 5 has 0 pets
6. House 6 has 0 pets
7. House 7 has 0 pets

Anna and Betty do not live in house 3. Charlie and Danny both live in house 1. How many different ways can these four people be assigned to the houses, considering the number of pets in each house? The final answer is 864.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem pet_distribution:
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = 864"
shows  "\<exists>siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish.
       (\<forall>anna betty charlie danny. 
         (anna \<noteq> goldfish \<and> betty \<noteq> goldfish \<and> charlie \<in> {siamese, persian, calico, minx} \<and> danny \<in> {siamese, persian, calico, minx}) \<longrightarrow>
         num_ways = count_ways siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem pet_distribution:
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = 864"
shows  "\<exists>siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish.
       (\<forall>anna betty charlie danny. 
         (anna \<noteq> goldfish \<and> betty \<noteq> goldfish \<and> charlie \<in> {siamese, persian, calico, minx} \<and> danny \<in> {siamese, persian, calico, minx}) \<longrightarrow>
         num_ways = count_ways siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: There are 864 ways to distribute pets among Anna, Betty, Charlie, and Danny, with the conditions that Anna and Betty cannot have a goldfish, and Charlie and Danny can only have a Siamese, Persian, Calico, or Minx cat. Find the number of ways to distribute the pets if there are Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx cats, Poodle and Golden Retriever dogs, and Goldfish available.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish :: nat
and anna betty charlie danny :: nat
and other_children :: nat
and total_arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "siamese = 1"
and h1 : "persian = 1"
and h2 : "calico = 1"
and h3 : "minx = 1"
and h4 : "poodle = 1"
and h5 : "golden_retriever = 1"
and h6 : "goldfish = 1"
and h7 : "anna = 1"
and h8 : "betty = 1"
and h9 : "charlie = 1"
and h10 : "danny = 1"
and h11 : "other_children = 3"
and h12 : "total_arrangements = 864"
shows  "total_arrangements = number_of_ways_to_assign_pets siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish anna betty charlie danny other_children"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish :: nat
and anna betty charlie danny :: nat
and other_children :: nat
and total_arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "siamese = 1"
and h1 : "persian = 1"
and h2 : "calico = 1"
and h3 : "minx = 1"
and h4 : "poodle = 1"
and h5 : "golden_retriever = 1"
and h6 : "goldfish = 1"
and h7 : "anna = 1"
and h8 : "betty = 1"
and h9 : "charlie = 1"
and h10 : "danny = 1"
and h11 : "other_children = 3"
and h12 : "total_arrangements = 864"
shows  "total_arrangements = number_of_ways_to_assign_pets siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish anna betty charlie danny other_children"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a group of children, there are four named children: Anna, Betty, Charlie, and Danny, and three other children. Each child will receive one of the following pets: Siamese, Persian, Calico, Minx, Poodle, Golden Retriever, and Goldfish. There are 864 total ways to assign the pets to the children. How many ways are there to assign the pets to the children?

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish :: nat
and anna betty charlie danny :: nat
and other_kids :: nat
assumes h0 : "siamese + persian + calico + minx = 4"
and h1 : "poodle + golden_retriever + goldfish = 3"
and h2 : "anna + betty + charlie + danny + other_kids = 7"
and h3 : "anna + betty \<noteq> goldfish"
and h4 : "charlie + danny = 2"
and h5 : "charlie + danny \<in> {siamese, persian, calico, minx}"
and h6 : "other_kids = 3"
shows  "number_of_ways = 864"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want? The final Answer is 864
 ### Proof
 Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
 For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes siamese persian calico minx poodle golden_retriever goldfish :: nat
and anna betty charlie danny :: nat
and other_kids :: nat
assumes h0 : "siamese + persian + calico + minx = 4"
and h1 : "poodle + golden_retriever + goldfish = 3"
and h2 : "anna + betty + charlie + danny + other_kids = 7"
and h3 : "anna + betty \<noteq> goldfish"
and h4 : "charlie + danny = 2"
and h5 : "charlie + danny \<in> {siamese, persian, calico, minx}"
and h6 : "other_kids = 3"
shows  "number_of_ways = 864"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
There are four types of cats: Siamese, Persian, Calico, and Minx. There are three types of dogs: Poodle, Golden Retriever, and Goldfish. There are seven children named Anna, Betty, Charlie, Danny, and three other kids.

The children have a total of 4 cats and 3 dogs. Charlie and Danny have two pets, both of which are cats. Anna and Betty do not have a goldfish. The other kids have three pets.

Find the number of ways the pets can be distributed among the children. The final answer is 864.

natural problem: Mr. Smith brings home 7 animals for his 7 children.  Each child will adopt a pet to be her or his own.  There are 4 different cats (a Siamese, a Persian, a Calico, and a Minx), 2 different dogs (a Poodle and a Golden Retriever), and a goldfish.  Anna and Betty refuse to take care of the goldfish, and Charlie and Danny insist on having cats.  The other 3 kids are easier to please -- they'll take anything.  In how many ways can Mr. Smith give the children pets they'll want?
natural solution: Charlie can take one of the 4 cats, and Danny can take one of the 3 remaining cats, so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give cats to these two kids. Since Anna and Betty can't take a goldfish, they select from the 4 remaining animals so there are $4\times 3=12$ ways to give pets to these two kids.
For the other three kids, there are $3\times 2\times 1=6$ ways to give out the remaining 3 pets. The answer is $12\times 12\times 6=\boxed{864}.$
